prompt.p: A 14-year-old athletic female has not undergone menarche. On average she runs 20 miles a week and eats a balanced diet (verified by her mother). Physical examination is normal with a body mass index (BMI) of 18. Haematological investigation reveals reduced gonadotrophins and oestradiol levels.
What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism) is Correct. This is either functional or organic. In this case it is functional leading to a reduction in serum gonadotrophin and oestradiol levels. It is seen in high-performance athletes with a low body weight.
Option A (Anorexia nervosa) is Incorrect. Indicated by body mass index <17.5 kg/m 2 , an overvalued idea of body weight, endocrine disturbance and self-induced weight loss.

Option B (Kallmann's syndrome) is Incorrect. Kallmann's syndrome is the presence of anosmia, delayed puberty and amenorrhoea. Low gonadotrophins and oestradiol levels are due to gonadotrophin-releasing hormone impaired release.

Option D (Testicular feminization syndrome) is Incorrect. Androgen intracellular receptor deficiency results in end-organ resistance to testosterone. Phenotypically female, these individuals have an absent uterus and blind ending vagina.
Option E (Turner's syndrome) is Incorrect. The patient has a karyotype 45XO, elevated gonadotrophins and low levels of oestradiol due to ovarian failure.

Option C (Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism) is Correct. This is either functional or organic. In this case it is functional leading to a reduction in serum gonadotrophin and oestradiol levels. It is seen in high-performance athletes with a low body weight.
Option A (Anorexia nervosa) is Incorrect. Indicated by body mass index <17.5 kg/m 2 , an overvalued idea of body weight, endocrine disturbance and self-induced weight loss.

Option B (Kallmann's syndrome) is Incorrect. Kallmann's syndrome is the presence of anosmia, delayed puberty and amenorrhoea. Low gonadotrophins and oestradiol levels are due to gonadotrophin-releasing hormone impaired release.

Option D (Testicular feminization syndrome) is Incorrect. Androgen intracellular receptor deficiency results in end-organ resistance to testosterone. Phenotypically female, these individuals have an absent uterus and blind ending vagina.
Option E (Turner's syndrome) is Incorrect. The patient has a karyotype 45XO, elevated gonadotrophins and low levels of oestradiol due to ovarian failure.
